text: Save us, O LORD our God, and gather us from among the heathen, to give thanks unto thy holy name, and to triumph in thy praise.
text_kjv: Save us, O LORD our God, and gather us from among the heathen, to give thanks unto thy holy name, and to triumph in thy praise.
text_niv: Save us, O Lord our God,and gather us from the nations,that we may give thanks to your holy nameand glory in your praise.
text_esv: Save us, O LORD our God, and gather us from among the nations, that we may give thanks to your holy name and glory in your praise.
text_nlt: Save us, O LORD our God!Gather us back from among the nations,so we can thank your holy nameand rejoice and praise you.
text_msg: Save us, God, our God!Gather us back out of exileSo we can give thanks to your holy nameand join in the glory when you are praised!
text_nasb: Save us, O LORD our God, And gather us from among the nations, To give thanks to Your holy name And glory in Your praise.
context: Psalm 106, a historical psalm, recounts Israel's repeated disobedience and God's enduring faithfulness despite their rebellion. Understanding the historical context is crucial. The 'heathen' referred to the nations surrounding Israel, whose practices often led the Israelites astray. Throughout their history, Israel faced periods of exile and dispersion among these nations due to their unfaithfulness to the covenant. This verse specifically echoes the longing for restoration and return from such exiles. The plea to be 'gathered from among the heathen' is not merely a request for physical repatriation but also for spiritual renewal and separation from pagan influences. The psalmist isn't simply asking to escape hardship, but to be returned to a place where they can properly worship and praise God. This verse resonates deeply with the exile experiences under Assyrian and Babylonian rule, periods where the Israelites were scattered and forced to live among people with different religious beliefs and customs. The psalm as a whole serves as a reminder of God's covenant promises and his unwavering commitment to his people, even when they fall short. It also emphasizes the importance of remembrance and repentance in maintaining a right relationship with God. The act of 'giving thanks unto thy holy name' and 'triumphing in thy praise' signify a renewed commitment to worship and a celebration of God's deliverance.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 106:47 encapsulates several profound themes. First, it acknowledges God as the sole source of salvation. The plea 'Save us, O LORD our God' affirms God's power and willingness to rescue his people from their predicament, whether it be physical exile or spiritual bondage. Second, it highlights the concept of gathering. This 'gathering' is both literal, referring to the return from exile, and metaphorical, representing the reunification of God's people in faith and obedience. It anticipates the future ingathering of all believers into God's kingdom. Third, the verse emphasizes the purpose of redemption: 'to give thanks unto thy holy name, and to triumph in thy praise.' Salvation is not merely an escape from suffering but a means to glorify God. Gratitude and praise are the appropriate responses to God's grace. This verse connects to the broader biblical narrative of covenant faithfulness. Despite Israel's repeated failings, God remains committed to his promises. His saving acts are always accompanied by a call to worship and obedience. The phrase 'holy name' points to God's character and attributes. Giving thanks to his holy name acknowledges his holiness, righteousness, and faithfulness. 'Triumphing in his praise' expresses joy and victory over the forces that oppose God and his people. It anticipates the ultimate triumph of God's kingdom over all evil. This verse also foreshadows the New Testament concept of being 'called out' from the world and gathered into the body of Christ. Believers are called out of darkness into light, from sin to righteousness, and from separation to fellowship.
application: The plea of Psalm 106:47 holds significant relevance for believers today, both individually and corporately. We can apply this verse in several ways. Firstly, recognize our own need for salvation. Like the Israelites, we often find ourselves 'scattered' and influenced by the 'heathen' culture around us â€“ materialism, secularism, and moral relativism. We need to cry out to God for deliverance from these influences and a return to his truth. Secondly, cultivate a spirit of gratitude and praise. When God answers our prayers and rescues us from difficult situations, we should respond with heartfelt thanksgiving and exuberant praise. This means actively engaging in worship, expressing our gratitude through our words and actions, and living lives that reflect God's goodness. Thirdly, seek to be gathered together with other believers. Isolation can weaken our faith and make us vulnerable to temptation. We should actively participate in the life of the church, supporting and encouraging one another. Fourthly, pray for the gathering of all believers into God's kingdom. This includes praying for the conversion of those who do not yet know Christ and for the unity of the church. Fifthly, examine our lives for areas where we have strayed from God's path. Repent of our sins and ask for his forgiveness and restoration. We should also be mindful of the dangers of conforming to the world and actively seek to live according to God's standards. Finally, remember that our ultimate purpose is to glorify God. Everything we do should be done with the intention of bringing honor and praise to his name. This includes our work, our relationships, and our leisure activities. By living lives that are centered on God, we can truly 'triumph in his praise'. This verse challenges us to live intentionally, prioritizing our relationship with God and actively seeking to live in accordance with his will. It's a call to continuous repentance, renewed commitment, and unwavering praise.
prayer: O Lord our God, we come before you with humble hearts, acknowledging our need for your saving grace. We confess that we often stray from your path, allowing the influences of the world to lead us astray. We ask that you would save us from these snares and gather us back into your loving embrace. Fill our hearts with gratitude for your countless blessings and empower us to live lives that bring glory to your holy name. Help us to triumph in your praise, both in our private moments of devotion and in our public expressions of worship. May our lives be a testament to your goodness and faithfulness, drawing others to experience your saving love. Unite us as your people, and help us to support and encourage one another in our faith journey. We pray for the lost and scattered, that they too may be gathered into your kingdom. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: In a modern context, being 'gathered from among the heathen' refers to separating ourselves from worldly values and influences that contradict God's word. It means actively choosing to live according to biblical principles rather than conforming to societal norms that are opposed to God.
